On 9/19/05, Ilja Preuss <preuss@...> wrote:
> junit@yahoogroups.com wr=
ote:
> > ClassDefNotFoundError is thrown when a class could not be loaded
>=
 > usually because its static initializer threw an exception.
> >
> > It's =
the most insidious of all Java exceptions
>
> Well, it's actually not an ex=
ception, but an error... ;)
>
> > because noone ever
> > knows what it mean=
s (we get about 3 support calls about it a day)
>
> It obviously means that=
 not class definition for the specified classname
> could be found. How cou=
ld it get more specific?

The problem is that ClassDefNotFoundError is usua=
lly (in my
experience) thrown as a result of an error in a static initializ=
er.
After all, it found the class (which is why you haven't seen a
ClassNot=
FoundException), but it can't load it.

The actual cause is the first excep=
tion seen, with the subsequent
ClassDefNotFoundError exceptions just maskin=
g the issue... yet another
reason why static initializers are evil. And whe=
n it's thrown by the
error handler of the first exception...
